{{Infobox artwork/wikidata}} '''''The Holy Family with Angels''''' (1645) is an [[oil painting]] on canvas by the [[Netherlands|Dutch]] landscape painter [[Rembrandt]]. It is an example of [[Dutch Golden Age painting]] and is now in the collection of the [[Hermitage Museum]].
== Description == This painting was documented by [[Hofstede de Groot]] in 1915, who wrote; "94. THE HOLY FAMILY WITH THE ANGELS. [[John Smith (art historian)|Sm. 72.]]; [[Wilhelm von Bode|Bode]] 321 ; [[Eugène Dutuit|Dutuit]] 59; [[Alfred von Wurzbach|Wb.]] 391 ; B.-HdG. 251. In the foreground of [[St. Joseph|Joseph's]] carpenter's workshop, the Virgin Mary sits on a low chair, holding a large open book on her left arm. She rests her left foot on a foot-warmer and leans over to the left to draw the green curtain of the cradle in which the Child lies asleep under a red fur-lined coverlet. Mary wears a deep red gown and dark blue skirt, and a white kerchief and cap. Behind her in half-shadow, Joseph, in a brown working-dress, is shaping a [[yoke]] with his axe. From above to the left child-angels flutter down, throwing a bright light on the Virgin and the cradle. Full-length figures, almost half life-size. Signed on the left at foot, "Rembrandt f. 1645 " ; canvas, 46 1/2 inches by 36 inches. An old copy without the angels was in the possession of an English dealer in 1899, and afterwards in the possession of a New York dealer. Another copy without the angels was in the sale : --London, June 7, 1912, No. 23 (£15 : 15s.). A pen-drawing for the picture is in the collection of [[Leon Bonnat]], Paris ; reproduced by Lippmann-Hofstede de Groot, No. 20. A study in chalk for the Child in the cradle was in the collection of [[John Postle Heseltine|J. P. Heseltine]], London, and is now in the collection of H. Oppenheim, London ; reproduced by Lippmann, No. i883. Engraved by J. Vendramini, 1836 ; by J. Sanders in outline in F. Labenski, ''Description de I'Ermitage'', i. 28. Etched by N. Mossoloff in ''Les Rembrandts de l' Ermitage''. Lithographed by H. Robillard in Gohier Desfontaines and P. Petit, ''Galerie de l' Ermitage'', i. 4. Mentioned by [[Carel Vosmaer|Vosmaer]], pp. 262, 537 ; by Bode, pp. 474, 599 ; by Dutuit, p. 38 ; by [[Emile Michel|Michel]], pp. 299, 566 [228-9, 441] ; by [[Gustav Friedrich Waagen|Waagen]], ''The Picture Gallery of the Hermitage'', p. 177. ''Sale''. Adriaen Bout, The Hague, August 11, 1733 (Hoet, i. 390), No. 81 (150 florins) ; said to measure 43 1/2 inches by 55 inches. In the [[Pierre Crozat|Crozat]] collection, Paris ; bought for the Hermitage by the [[Catherine the Great|Empress Catherine ii]]. In the Hermitage Palace, Petrograd, 1901 catalogue, No. 796 [said by Sm. in 1836 to be well worth £2100]."<ref>[https://archive.org/stream/catalogueraisonn06hofsuoft#page/76/mode/1up Entry 94 for ''''The Holy Family with Angels''] in Hofstede de Groot, 1915</ref>
==Unusual portrayal in home setting== [[File:Harmensz van Rijn Rembrandt - Святое семейство - Google Art Project (cropped for mother and child).jpg|thumb|The baby Jesus is wearing a skull-cap with band known as a [[valhoed]] and he is propped up with cushions into a sitting position as was customary at that time]] Rembrandt portrays the [[Holy Family]] as a typical family of [[Amsterdam]] in his day. In the foreground Jesus is asleep in the same style of wicker crib that can be seen in period paintings of mothers with babies by [[Pieter de Hooch]]. Mary looks up from her book to take a peek at the sleeping child under the crib curtain (Dutch: ''klamboe''). In the background Joseph is working on making a [[yoke]].The yoke refers both to the coming of the Lord according to [[Isaiah]] ("For the yoke of their burden, and the bar across their shoulders, the rod of their oppressor, you have broken as on the day of Midian"), as well as the words of Jesus according to [[Matthew the Apostle]] ("Come to me, all you who are weary and burdened, and I will give you rest. Take my yoke upon you and learn from me, for I am gentle and humble in heart, and you will find rest for your souls, for my yoke is easy and my burden is light").
Other "Holy Family" paintings by Rembrandt or his school are: <gallery> File:Rembrandt, The Holy Family with a Curtain, 1646, Museum Schloss Wilhelmshöhe, Kassel.jpg|[[Gemäldegalerie Alte Meister (Kassel)]]. File:Rembrandt - Holy Family - WGA19116.jpg|[[Louvre]]. File:De heilige familie bij avond Rijksmuseum SK-A-4119.jpeg|[[Rijksmuseum]]. </gallery>
== References == {{reflist}} *[https://archive.org/stream/catalogueraisonn07smituoft#page/29/mode/1up 72. ''The Holy Family''] in Smith's catalogue raisonné of 1836 *[https://rkd.nl/en/explore/images/31208 ''The Holy Family with Angels''] in the [[RKD]] * [https://www.hermitagemuseum.org/wps/portal/hermitage/digital-collection/01.+Paintings/43400/ ''The Holy Family with Angels''], in the Hermitage website
{{Commons category}} {{Authority control}} {{Rembrandt}} {{Authority control}}

revision.comment: /* Critical response */the work's name is "The New York Times"
revision.text:
{{Infobox film | name = The Human Stain | image = HumanStainPoster.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Robert Benton]] | producer = {{Plain list| * [[Tom Rosenberg]] * [[Gary Lucchesi]] * [[Scott Steindorff]] * [[Bob Weinstein]] * [[Harvey Weinstein]] }} | screenplay = [[Nicholas Meyer]] | based on = {{based on|''[[The Human Stain]]''|[[Philip Roth]]}} | starring = {{Plain list| * [[Anthony Hopkins]] * [[Nicole Kidman]] * [[Gary Sinise]] }} | music = [[Rachel Portman]] | cinematography = [[Jean-Yves Escoffier]] | editing = [[Christopher Tellefsen]] | studio = [[Lakeshore Entertainment]] | distributor = [[Miramax Films]] | released = {{film date|2003|8|29|[[Venice Film Festival|Venice]]|2003|10|29|France|2003|10|31|United States|2003|12|18|Germany}} | runtime = 106 minutes | country = {{Plainlist| * United States * Germany * France }} | language = English | budget = $30 million | gross = $24.9 million }} '''''The Human Stain''''' is a 2003 [[drama film]] directed by [[Robert Benton]]. Its screenplay, by [[Nicholas Meyer]], is based on the [[The Human Stain|novel of the same name]] by [[Philip Roth]]. The film stars [[Anthony Hopkins]] and [[Nicole Kidman]].
==Plot== In the late 1990s, writer [[Nathan Zuckerman]] ([[Gary Sinise]]) has settled in a lakeside [[New England]] cabin following his second divorce and a battle with [[prostate cancer]]. His quiet life is interrupted by Coleman Silk ([[Anthony Hopkins]]), a former dean and professor of classics at local Athena College, who was forced to resign after being accused of making a [[racist]] remark in class. Coleman's wife died suddenly following the scandal, and he wants to avenge his loss of career and companion by writing a book about the events with Nathan's assistance.
The project is placed on the back burner when Coleman has an affair with Faunia Farley ([[Nicole Kidman]]), a considerably younger, semi-literate woman who supports herself by working menial jobs, including at the college. Their relationship is threatened by the faculty members who forced Coleman from his job and by Faunia's [[stalker]] ex-husband Lester ([[Ed Harris]]), a mentally unbalanced [[Vietnam War]] veteran who blames her for the deaths of their children in an accident. Flashbacks of Coleman's life reveal to the audience his secret: he is an African American who has "[[passing (sociology)|passed]]" as a white Jewish man for most of his adult life.
==Cast== * [[Anthony Hopkins]] as Coleman Silk * [[Nicole Kidman]] as Faunia Farley * [[Gary Sinise]] as Nathan Zuckerman * [[Ed Harris]] as Lester Farley * [[Wentworth Miller]] as Young Coleman Silk * [[Jacinda Barrett]] as Steena Paulsson * [[Mimi Kuzyk]] as Delphine Roux * [[Clark Gregg]] as Nelson Primus * [[Anna Deavere Smith]] as Dorothy Silk * [[Phyllis Newman]] as Iris Silk * [[Mili Avital]] as Young Iris * [[Harry Lennix]] as Clarence Silk * [[Tom Rack]] as Bob Cat * [[Lizan Mitchell]] as Ernestine Silk * [[Danny Blanco-Hall]] as Walter Silk
==Release== The film debuted at the [[Venice Film Festival]]. It was shown at the [[Toronto International Film Festival]], the [[Bergen International Film Festival]], and the Hollywood Film Festival before its theatrical release in the US.
===Box office=== The film grossed $5,381,908 in the US and $19,481,896 in foreign markets for a total worldwide box office of $24,863,304 against a budget of $30 million.<ref>[http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=humanstain.htm ''The Human Stain''] Box Office Mojo</ref>
{{Anchor|Reception|Critics}}
===Critical response=== ''The Human Stain'' received mixed reviews. Review aggregator [[Rotten Tomatoes]] reports that 41% of 148 professional critics gave the film a positive review, with a [[rating average]] of 5.5 out of 10. The site's consensus is that "Though the acting is fine, the leads are miscast, and the story is less powerful on screen than on the page."<ref>[http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/human_stain/ "The Human Stain"], Rotten Tomatoes</ref>
In his review in ''[[The New York Times]]'', A.O. Scott called it "an honorable B+ term paper of a movie: sober, scrupulous and earnestly respectful of its literary source . . . The filmmakers explicate Mr. Roth's themes with admirable clarity and care and observe his characters with delicate fondness, but they cannot hope to approximate the brilliance and rapacity of his voice, which holds all the novel's disparate elements together. Without the active intervention of Mr. Roth's intelligence . . . the story fails to cohere . . . At its best - which also tends to be at its quietest - ''The Human Stain'' allows you both to care about its characters and to think about the larger issues that their lives represent. Its deepest flaw is an inability to link those moments of empathy and insight into a continuous drama, to suggest that the characters' lives keep going when they are not on screen."<ref>{{cite web |date= |author= A.O. Scott |url=https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9505E4D81430F932A05753C1A9659C8B63|title=Movie Review - FILM REVIEW; Secrets of the Skin, And of the Heart | work = NYTimes.com|publisher=}}</ref>
[[Roger Ebert]] of the ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' observed, "We have to suspend disbelief over the casting, but that's easier since we can believe the stories of these people. Not many movies probe into matters of identity or adaptation. Most movie characters are like [[List of Greek mythological figures|Greek gods]] and [[comic book]] heroes: We learn their roles and powers at the beginning of the story, and they never change. Here are complex, troubled, flawed people, brave enough to breathe deeply and take one more risk with their lives."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20031031/REVIEWS/310310303/1023|title=The Human Stain Movie Review & Film Summary (2003) - Roger Ebert|first=Roger|last=Ebert|publisher=}}</ref>
In the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'', [[Mick LaSalle]] called it "a mediocre movie . . . [that] falls victim to a fatal lack of narrative drive, suspense and drama. Kidman and Hopkins are wrong for their roles, and that, combined with a pervading inevitability, cuts the film off from any sustained vitality. The result is something admirable but lifeless."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2003/10/31/DD231134.DTL|title='Human Stain' doesn't quite wash / Philip Roth adaptation a nice effort but ultimately unbelievable|publisher=}}</ref>
[[David Stratton]] of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' described it as "an intelligent adaptation of Philip Roth's arguably unfilmable novel powered by two eye-catching performances . . . A key problem Benton is unable to avoid is that Hopkins and Miller don't look (or talk) the least bit like one another. Miller, who gives a strong, muted performance, convinces as a light-skinned African-American in a way Hopkins never does, which is not to suggest that the Welsh-born actor doesn't give another intelligent, powerful portrayal. It's just that the believability gap looms large."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117921675.html?categoryid=31&cs=1&p=0|title=Review: ‘The Human Stain’|first=David|last=Stratton|date=3 September 2003|publisher=}}</ref>
In ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', [[Peter Travers]] said, "Hopkins and Kidman . . . are both as mesmerizing as they are miscast . . . ''The Human Stain'' is heavy going. It's the flashes of dramatic lightning that make it a trip worth taking."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/reviews/movie/_/id/5947821/rid/5947822/|title=Movie Review|publisher=}}</ref>
''[[The Times]]'' of London called it "sapping and unbelievable [[melodrama]] . . . an unforgivably turgid lecture about [[political correctness]]."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,7943-971961,00.html|title=The Times & The Sunday Times|publisher=}}</ref>
==Awards and nominations== {{Anchor|Awards|Accolades}} * [[American Film Institute Awards 2003|American Film Institute Award for Best Movies of 2003]] ('''winner''') * [[Washington D.C. Area Film Critics Association Awards 2003|Washington D.C. Area Film Critics Association Award for Best Supporting Actress]] (Anna Deavere Smith, '''winner''') * [[Black Reel Awards#Best Supporting Actress in a Motion Picture|Black Reel Award for Best Supporting Actress in a Motion Picture]] (Smith, '''winner''') * [[Black Reel Awards#Best Actor in a Motion Picture|Black Reel Award for Best Actor in a Motion Picture]] (Wentworth Miller, nominee) * [[Black Reel Awards#Best Breakthrough Performance|Black Reel Award for Best Breakthrough Performance]] (Miller, nominee)
==Music== {{Anchor|Soundtrack}} The soundtrack to ''The Human Stain'' was released September 23, 2003.

revision.text:
{{Infobox artwork | image_file = Old guitarist chicago.jpg | painting_alignment = | image_size = | title = The Old Guitarist | medium = [[Oil painting|Oil on panel]] | artist = [[Pablo Picasso]] | year = 1903–04 | height_metric = 122.9 | width_metric = 82.6 | height_imperial = | width_imperial = | city = | museum = [[Art Institute of Chicago]] | coordinates = <!-- Only use for the exact coordinates of the artwork itself (and only where known) and not for the coordinates of the museum. Leave blank if coordinates are not known. --> | owner = }}
'''''The Old Guitarist''''' is an oil painting by [[Pablo Picasso]] created late 1903{{snds}}early 1904. It depicts an old, blind, haggard man with threadbare clothing weakly hunched over his guitar, playing in the streets of [[Barcelona, Spain]]. It is currently on display at the [[Art Institute of Chicago]] as part of the [[Helen Birch Bartlett Memorial Collection]].<ref name="artic">[http://www.artic.edu/aic/collections/artwork/28067 Art Institute of Chicago, ''The Old Guitarist'', About this work]</ref>
At the time of ''The Old Guitarist''’s creation, [[Modern art|Modernism]], [[Impressionism]], [[Post-Impressionism]], and [[Symbolism (arts)|Symbolism]] had merged and created an overall movement called [[Expressionism]] which greatly influenced Picasso’s style. Furthermore, [[El Greco]], Picasso’s poor standard of living, and the suicide of a dear friend influenced Picasso’s style at the time which came to be known as his [[Blue Period]].<ref name="artic" /> Several x-rays, infrared images and examinations by curators revealed three different figures hidden behind the old guitarist.
==Blue Period==
At the time, having renounced his classical and traditional education and searching for fame, Picasso and his friend [[Carlos Casagemas]] moved to Paris. A year later, Casagemas became hopelessly miserable from a failed love affair and committed suicide. Picasso was greatly afflicted by this event and was soon depressed and desolate. In addition, Picasso was very poor. His poverty made him identify and relate to beggars, prostitutes and other downtrodden outcasts in society.<ref name="artic" />
These events and circumstances were the impetus for the beginning of Picasso’s [[Blue Period]] which lasted from 1901 to 1904. The Blue Period is identified by the flat expanses of blues, greys and blacks, melancholy figures lost in contemplation, and a deep and significant tragedy. After the Blue Period came [[Picasso's Rose Period]], and eventually the [[Cubism]] movement which Picasso co-founded.<ref name="artic" />
==Analysis==
Elements in ''The Old Guitarist'' were carefully chosen to generate a reaction from the spectator. For example, the [[monochromatic]] color scheme creates flat, two-dimensional forms that dissociate the guitarist from time and place. In addition, the overall muted blue palette creates a general tone of melancholy and accentuates the tragic and sorrowful theme. The sole use of oil on panel causes a darker and more theatrical mood. Oil tends to blend the colors together without diminishing brightness, creating an even more cohesive dramatic composition.<ref>[http://www.123HelpMe.com/view.asp?id=46491 Essay on ''The Old Guitarist'' ]</ref>
Furthermore, the guitarist, although muscular, shows little sign of life and appears to be close to death, implying little comfort in the world and accentuating the misery of his situation. Details are eliminated and scale is manipulated to create elongated and elegant proportions while intensifying the silent contemplation of the guitarist and a sense of spirituality. The large, brown guitar is the only significant shift in color found in the painting;<ref name="artic" /> its dull brown, prominent against the blue background, becomes the center and focus. The guitar comes to represent the guitarist’s world and only hope for survival. This blind and poor subject depends on his guitar and the small income he can earn from his music for survival. Some art historians believe this painting expresses the solitary life of an artist and the natural struggles that come with the career. Therefore, music, or art, becomes a burden and an alienating force that isolates artists from the world.<ref>[http://blogs.princeton.edu/writingart8/archives/2004/12/the_blue_period.html Blue Period Music: ''The Old Guitarist'' ] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720030643/http://blogs.princeton.edu/writingart8/archives/2004/12/the_blue_period.html |date=2011-07-20 }}</ref> And yet, despite the isolation, the guitarist (artist) depends on the rest of society for survival. All of these emotions reflect Picasso’s predicament at the time and his criticism of the state of society. ''The Old Guitarist'' becomes an allegory of human existence.<ref name="artic" />
[[Paul Mariani]], a biographer of [[Wallace Stevens]], presented his analysis of the painting as a counterpoint to objections raised by Stevens concerning the origin of his own poem titled ''[[The Man With the Blue Guitar]]'' stating, "Despite his repeatedly denying it, Stevens does seem to have a particular painting in mind here: Picasso's 1903 ''The Old Guitarist'', which portrays an old man with white hair and beard sitting distorted and cross-legged as he plays his guitar. If Picasso attempted to portray the world of poverty and abject misery, it was because that had been his own plight as a struggling young artist in Barcelona, where he painted many pictures including this one, of the poor. The painting is almost entirely done in monochromatic blues and blue-blacks, except for the guitar itself, which is painted in a slightly warmer brown. The man is blind but, no longer seeing the world around him, he sees more deeply into the reality within."<ref>Paul Mariani. Biography of Wallace Stevens. Page 226.</ref>
In the ''Old Guitarist'', Picasso may have drawn upon [[George Frederic Watts]]'s painting of ''[[Hope (painting)|Hope]]'' (1886), which similarly depicts a hunched, helpless musician with a distorted angular form and predominantly blue tone.<ref name="tate.org">{{cite web |ref=harv|year= 2004 |url = http://www.tate.org.uk/context-comment/articles/where-theres-life-theres|title = Where there's life there's|publisher = [[Tate]]| accessdate = 12 March 2010 | last=Barlow| first= Paul |quote=}}</ref>
==Infrared discoveries==
[[File:OldGuitaristLady.jpg|thumb|Detail showing an image beneath]]
Recent x-rays and examinations by curators found three figures peering behind the old guitarist’s body. The three figures are an old woman with her head bent forward, a young mother with a small child kneeling by her side, and an animal on the right side of the canvas. Despite unclear imagery in crucial areas of the canvas, experts determined that at least two different paintings are found beneath ''The Old Guitarist''.<ref name="X-Ray">[http://www.google.com/imgres?imgurl=http://www.harpiesbizarre.com/art/art-OldGuitaristLady.jpg&imgrefurl=http://www.harpiesbizarre.com/art.htm&usg=__dVLakrOuVjE-datGwb5ZVeae1bA=&h=365&w=391&sz=80&hl=en&start=0&zoom=1&tbnid=dUwC8IDLqFleLM:&tbnh=143&tbnw=154&ei=RpN5Td_uH4aisQPI3cGKAw&prev=/images%3Fq%3DThe%2Bold%2Bguitarist%26um%3D1%26hl%3Den%26client%3Dsafari%26sa%3DN%26rls%3Den%26biw%3D1290%26bih%3D784%26tbs%3Disch:1&um=1&itbs=1&iact=hc&vpx=243&vpy=279&dur=2536&hovh=217&hovw=232&tx=203&ty=124&oei=RpN5Td_uH4aisQPI3cGKAw&page=1&ndsp=37&ved=1t:429,r:11,s:0 X-Ray Image of ''The Old Guitarist'']</ref>
In 1998, researchers used an [[infrared]] camera to penetrate the uppermost layer of paint (the composition of ''The Old Guitarist'') and clearly saw the second-most composition. By using this camera, researchers were able to discover a young mother seated in the center of the composition, reaching out with her left arm to her kneeling child at her right, and a calf or sheep on the mother’s left side. Clearly defined, the young woman has long, flowing dark hair and a thoughtful expression.<ref name="Infrared">[http://www.google.com/imgres?imgurl=http://www.artic.edu/aic/conservation/revealingpicasso/images/xray_200pxl.jpg&imgrefurl=http://www.artic.edu/aic/conservation/revealingpicasso/exam_xray.html&usg=__mzLq_wqI538Q2SMkL8GjIF4gWPE=&h=299&w=200&sz=23&hl=en&start=0&zoom=1&tbnid=bHttlAJiL4gtBM:&tbnh=137&tbnw=97&ei=iJN5TfHIHY-isAPlqOWKAw&prev=/images%3Fq%3DThe%2Bold%2Bguitarist%2Binfrared%26um%3D1%26hl%3Den%26client%3Dsafari%26rls%3Den%26biw%3D1290%26bih%3D784%26tbs%3Disch:10%2C131&um=1&itbs=1&iact=rc&dur=465&oei=iJN5TfHIHY-isAPlqOWKAw&page=1&ndsp=26&ved=1t:429,r:24,s:0&tx=79&ty=40&biw=1290&bih=784 Infrared Image of ''The Old Guitarist'']</ref>
The Art Institute of Chicago shared its infrared images with the [[Cleveland Museum of Art]] and the [[National Gallery of Art]] in Washington, D.C., where curator William Robinson identified a sketch by Picasso sent to his friend Max Jacob in a letter. It revealed the same composition of mother and child, but it had a cow licking the head of a small calf. In a letter to Jacob, Picasso reveals he was painting this composition a few months before he began ''The Old Guitarist''. Despite these discoveries, the reason Picasso did not complete the composition with a mother and child, and how the older woman fitted into the history of the canvas, remain unknown.<ref name="X-Ray" /><ref name="Infrared" />
==See also== *''[[The Man With the Blue Guitar]]'', 1937 [[Wallace Stevens]] poem
==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}}

''The Old Guitarist'' Meets New Technology]. Rep. The Art Institute of Chicago, 2001. Web. 25 Feb. 2011 *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110720030643/http://blogs.princeton.edu/writingart8/archives/2004/12/the_blue_period.html "Picasso's Musical Instruments: Blue Period Music: ''The Old Guitarist''." Princeton University Blog Service]. Web. 10 Mar. 2011 *[http://www.theartistpablopicasso.com/pablo-picasso-painting-old-guitarist.htm "Pablo Ruiz Picasso Painting ''The Old Guitarist'' - TheArtistPabloPicasso.com]." The Artist Pablo Picasso Art and Biography - Theartistpablopicasso.com. Web. 10 Mar. 2011 *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110507151733/http://gallery.sjsu.edu/paris/symbolism/introduction.html "Symbolism." SJSU Digital Art Lobby]. Web. 10 Mar. 2011
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110623183159/http://www.people.vcu.edu/~djbromle/modern04/paulh/index.htm Picasso's Blue Period] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071210203401/http://www.artic.edu/aic/conservation/revealingpicasso/ The Art Institute of Chicago: Revealing Picasso Conservation Project] *[http://www.notablebiographies.com/Pe-Pu/Picasso-Pablo.html Biography of Pablo Picasso] *[http://www.artic.edu/collections/conservation/revealing-picasso-conservation-project/art-historical-research ''The Old Guitarist'', Art-Historical Research, Art Institute of Chicago]

{{Infobox book | name = The Wolf of Wall Street | title_orig = | translator = | image = The wolf of wall street - bookcover.jpg | border = | caption = Hardcover edition | author = [[Jordan Belfort]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | subject = <!-- Subject is not relevant for fiction --> | genre = Non-fiction | publisher = [[Bantam Books]] | release_date = September 25, 2007 | english_release_date = | media_type = Print, e-book, audiobook | pages = 528 pp. | isbn = 978-0553805468 | dewey = | congress = | oclc = | preceded_by = | followed_by = [[Catching the Wolf of Wall Street]] }}
'''''The Wolf of Wall Street''''' is a [[memoir]] by former [[stockbroker]] and trader [[Jordan Belfort]], first published in September 2007 by [[Bantam Books]],<ref>{{Cite book|publisher=[[amazon.com]]|title = The Wolf of Wall Street by Jordan Belfort|asin = 0553805460}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/522776.The_Wolf_of_Wall_Street|publisher=[[goodreads.com]]|title=The Wolf of Wall Street (The Wolf Of Wall Street #1) by Jordan Belfort (Goodreads Author)|accessdate=2015-02-16}}</ref> then adapted into a 2013 [[The Wolf of Wall Street (2013 film)|film of the same name]] (directed by [[Martin Scorsese]] and starring [[Leonardo DiCaprio]] as Belfort). Belfort's autobiographical account was continued by ''[[Catching the Wolf of Wall Street]]'', published in 2009.
==Overview== Belfort tells his real-life story of creating [[Stratton Oakmont]], a brokerage house engaged in [[pump and dump]] schemes with [[penny stock]]s. The firm was shut down by regulators in the late 1990s, and Belfort was jailed for securities fraud.
==See also== *[[Boiler room (business)]] *''[[Great Salad Oil Swindle]]'' by [[Norman Charles Miller]] *''[[Octopus: Sam Israel, the Secret Market, and Wall Street's Wildest Con|Octopus]]'' by Guy Lawson *[[Microcap stock fraud]] *''[[Rogue Trader (book)|Rogue Trader]]'' by [[Nick Leeson]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *{{youtube|6gY8jRNh-4|Jordan Belfort: In-depth interview with The Wolf of Wall Street}} *[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/film-news/10560364/The-Wolf-of-Wall-Street-meet-the-real-bad-guy.html Movie review by ''The Telegraph''] *[http://www.esquire.com/entertainment/news/a26702/real-wolf-of-wall-street/ Movie review by ''Esquire'']

[[File:Josephine Baker 1950.jpg|thumb|right|[[Josephine Baker]] in 1950]] A '''''vedette''''' is the main female artist of a show derived from [[cabaret]] and its genres ([[revue]], [[vaudeville]], [[music hall]] or [[burlesque]]).
The purpose of the vedette in a cabaret or nightclub show is to entertain the public. The vedette has to know how to [[triple threat (entertainer)|sing, dance and act]] on stage. Depending on the quality of its show, career or mastery of one or more stage talents, can be considered a ''super vedette'' or ''first vedette''. Generally a vedette is a woman with physical presence, personality and charisma that captivates the public. In addition to singing, dancing and acting, vedettes often included groups of dancers, flashy and revealing costumes, magicians, comedians, jugglers, and even performing animals. Vedettes specializing in burlesque generally do striptease and may also perform nude on stage.
In the 20th century, vedette shows were successful in the cabarets, theaters and nightclubs of countries such as [[Spain]], [[France]], [[Argentina]] and [[Mexico]]. [[Paris]] and [[Las Vegas]] were considered the main cradle of the vedettes.
==Etymology== ''Vedette'' is a French word originally used to designate an artist of great fame and notoriety.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.le-dictionnaire.com/definition.php?mot=vedette|title=Le Dictionnaire - Définition vedette|website=www.le-dictionnaire.com|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref>
The term underwent changes over the years. From the early twentieth century, it began to be used to designate the main female artists of the shows of a cabaret such as burlesque, vaudeville, music hall or revue. The zenith of fame and popularity of these women coincided with various historical moments of 20th century sexual liberation: the 1920s, 1940s and 1970s.
The vedettes began their rise in popularity in France at the beginning of the 20th century. After France, they have gained greater popularity in Latin countries, both in Europe (Spain) and North and South America (Argentina and Mexico), where they caused a furor in the nightlife at different times. The term is little used in Anglo-Saxon countries, although in the United States there are very popular shows of cabaret and burlesque in the city of Las Vegas, where it is often confused with so-called [[showgirl]]s. Venues such as [[Le Lido]], the [[Moulin Rouge]], and the [[Crazy Horse]] in France. The [[Teatro Maipo]] and the [[Teatro El Nacional]] in Argentina, and the [[Teatro de la Ciudad |Teatro de la Ciudad "Esperanza Iris"]] in Mexico are or were famous for their vedette shows.
==Europe==
===France=== [[File:Le Lido.jpg|thumb|right|[[Le Lido]] of Paris]] France is considered the cradle of vedettes worldwide. Its capital, [[Paris]], has been home to some of the most famous cabarets in the world. Among these are the [[Moulin Rouge]] and the [[Folies Bergère de Paris]], pioneers of night shows in which the vedettes appeared on the scene half naked and doing [[Tableau vivant]]. Other famous venues are the [[Le Lido]] and [[Bataclan (theatre)|Bataclan]], also famous for their vaudeville and Revues. In more recent times, this group of entertainment centers would be joined by [[Crazy Horse (cabaret)|Crazy Horse]].
Among the main vedettes of France are considered the "Three Graces" of Belle Époque: [[Émilienne d'Alençon]], [[Liane de Pougy]], and [[La Bella Otero]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.edwardianpromenade.com/sex/the-courtesan/|title=The Courtesan|date=14 September 2011|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> The famous [[Mistinguett]] became one of the most popular French artists of her time and the most important woman in the world of the spectacle,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.biografiasyvidas.com/biografia/m/mistinguett.htm|title=Biografia de Mistinguett|website=www.biografiasyvidas.com|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> while Madame Rasimi is remembered as the founder of the Bataclan. Another outstanding figure was [[Gina Palerme]].
At the beginning of the century, the novelist [[Colette]] was also distinguished by acting in shows of magazine. Another prominent figure at that time is the world-famous Dutch spy [[Mata Hari]].
The legendary [[Cléo de Mérode]] of the Folies Bergère was another of the great stars of the Parisian nightlife of the twentieth century.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.portalsolidario.net/ocio/visu/biografia.php?rowid=10182|title=Biografía insólita. Cleo de Mérode, la bailarina más deseada|website=www.portalsolidario.net|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> [[File:Mistinguett Moulin Rouge.jpg|thumb|left|[[Mistinguett]] at the [[Moulin Rouge]]]]
[[Joséphine Baker]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmgww.com/stars/baker/about/biography.html|title=Biography - The Official Licensing Website of Josephine Baker|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> of [[United States|American]] origin, is remembered as one of the most important vedettes of the twentieth century. Her "Revue Nègre", which included a [[jazz]] orchestra, caused a sensation in the Parisian cabarets. Her exotic dance form, her uninhibited sexuality and her minimal dress (which included a skirt made with bananas) were more attractive to [[Europe]]ans than to [[United States|Americans]]. She became the star of Parisian nights and even opened her own club, Chez ''Josephine''.
Another important figure was [[Coccinelle]], considered the first transsexual vedette in history.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ww38.coccinelleshow.com/|archive-url=https://archive.is/20161228073700/http://ww38.coccinelleshow.com/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=28 December 2016|title=''Biography of Coccinelle in her official web page''|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> The actress and singer [[Liliane Montevecchi]] stood out as vedette in the Folies Bergère in the 1970s, and eventually conquered [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]]. Another figure of the time was the Italian Xenia Monty.
In recent times the vedette shows emphasize figures like [[Arielle Dombasle]] (known as the vedette-like Dolorès Sugar Rose) and Marlène Mourreau.
===Spain=== [[File:La Belle Otero - Folies Bergere.jpg|thumb|right|[[La Bella Otero]] in an 1894 Folies Bergère poster]] One of the first vedettes that stood out in [[Spain]] are La Bella Otero, a celebrated courtesan who settled in France, one of the most outstanding personages of the Belle Époque in the artistic circles and the gallant life of Paris;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.culturagalega.org/album/detalle.php?id=53|title=La Bella Otero - Álbum de mulleres - culturagalega.org|website=www.culturagalega.org|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> Luisa Esteso, famous comedian actress; Encarnación Fernández, who had most of her career in Argentina;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.maipo.com.ar/historia_1927.htm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006142355/http://www.maipo.com.ar/historia_1927.htm|dead-url=yes|archive-date=6 October 2014|title=Teatro Maipo|date=6 October 2014|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> [[Celia Gámez]] (of Argentine origin), one of the most popular stars of Spain in the first half of the twentieth century, and who owes much of the splendor of the Revues;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lazarzuela.webcindario.com/BIO/gamez.htm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080327224443/http://lazarzuela.webcindario.com/BIO/gamez.htm|dead-url=no|archive-date=27 March 2008|title=The Career of Celia Gámez|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> Paquita Garzón;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hemeroteca.abc.es/|title=Hemeroteca de ABC - abc.es|website=hemeroteca.abc.es|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> Rosario Guerrero (called "The Beautiful Guerrero"); Rosita Rodrigo; Tina de Jarque,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.es/local-comunidad-valenciana/20130420/abci-misterio-vedette-tina-jarque-201304201341.html|title=El misterio de la vedette Tina de Jarque|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> [[Rosario Soler]] "La Patita",<ref>{{cite web|url=https://rosariosoler.wordpress.com/|title=Rosario Soler. La Patita. Biografía de la tiple malagueña.|website=Rosario Soler. La Patita. Biografía de la tiple malagueña.|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> [[Paquita Escribano]], [[Carmen Tórtola Valencia]], specialist in oriental dances and pioneer of women's liberation,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jotdown.es/2016/01/tortola-valencia-entre-la-danza-y-el-deseo/|title=Tórtola Valencia: entre la danza y el deseo|date=31 January 2016|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> and the sisters Laura and Victoria Pinillos.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1970/11/04/093.html|title=ABC (Madrid) - 04/11/1970, p. 93 - ABC.es Hemeroteca|website=hemeroteca.abc.es|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref>
The 1940s highlighted figures such as [[Trini Alonso]], [[María Antinea]] (also famous in Argentina and Mexico); Maruja Boldoba, [[Florinda Chico]], Gema del Rio, the popular Manolita Chen and her company; Teresita Silva; Maruja Tomás and [[Helga Liné]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lazarzuela.webcindario.com/BIO/silvateresita.htm|title=Teresita Silva|website=lazarzuela.webcindario.com|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref>
The 1950s highlighted stars like [[Mary Begoña]], one of the comedic actresses par excellence of the Spanish scene;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://larevistamusical.blogspot.com/search?max-results=18|title=HISTORIAS DE LA REVISTA MUSICAL ESPAÑOLA|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> Licia Calderón, [[Queta Claver]] (that became one of the major vedettes of Spain);<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elmundo.es/elmundo/2003/05/05/cultura/1052132283.html|title=elmundo.es - Fallece la actriz Queta Claver, una de las vedettes más populares|website=www.elmundo.es|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> Raquel Daina;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.madridiario.es/noticia/231266|title=Raquel Daina: superviviente de la pasarela|first=|last=Madridiario|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> [[Marujita Díaz]], considered as the "Queen of the Copla" and "Queen of the Spanish Music Revue" and [[Carmen de Lirio]], famous during the dictatorship.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.enciclopedia-aragonesa.com/voz.asp?voz_id=8035|title=Gran Enciclopedia Aragonesa Online|first=DiCom Medios|last=SL|website=www.enciclopedia-aragonesa.com|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref>
In the sixties, famous figures such as [[Mary Santpere]], called "La Reina del Paralelo" (The Queen of the Parallel) reached the fame of Barcelona's homonymous street, where the greatest number of theaters were concentrated in the 20th century; Rosita Amores, pioneer of the erotic cabaret in the mid-1960s, and who knew how to outwit Franco's censorship in times when eroticism in Spain was confined to the private sphere, becoming a popular symbol of entertainment in the Valencian Community; [[Marisol Ayuso]]; Ingrid Garbo, of German origin; [[Vicky Lagos]]; Vicky Lusson; [[Katia Loritz]];<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elmundo.es/cultura/2015/08/17/55d1f230ca4741806b8b4587.html|title=Muere la actriz Katia Loritz, una de las 'Chicas de la Cruz Roja'|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> [[Esperanza Roy]], and [[Lina Morgan]], one of the country's most momentous comic strips.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elpais.com/articulo/cultura/MORGAN/_LINA/Lina/Morgan/picara/vencio/escultural/elpepicul/19850127elpepicul_9/Tes,|title=Article about Lina Morgan|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> [[Sara Montiel]], deserves special mention, who along with her prestigious film career, excelled in shows as a vedette from this decade.
In the 1970s María José Cantudo starred in the first full-length female nude (seen through a mirror) of Spanish cinema;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/blanco.y.negro/1976/01/03/051.html|title=Blanco y Negro (Madrid) - 03/01/1976, p. 51 - ABC.es Hemeroteca|website=hemeroteca.abc.es|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> Eva León Conde<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.biografias.es/famosos/eva-leon.html|title=Eva León - Biografía de Eva León|website=www.biografias.es|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> and [[Barbara Rey]] were also popular vedettes of the period.
From the 1980s and 1990s stand out figures such as Lita Claver "La Maña";<ref>{{cite web|url=https://javierbarreiro.wordpress.com/2010/01/19/lita-claver-la-mana/|title=LITA CLAVER “LA MAÑA”|date=19 January 2010|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> [[Norma Duval]], one of the last stars of the traditional magazine, a type of spectacle that during those years was in decline and that was maintained mainly thanks to the tourists who visited Paris;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mx.hola.com/biografias/norma-duval/biografia/|title=Norma Duval. Noticias, fotos y biografía de Norma Duval|first1=|last1=Mx.Hola.com|first2=|last2=Hola.com|website=mx.hola.com|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> Tania Doris, another one of the last representatives of the sort in Spain ; Paloma Hurtado, María José Nieto "Maripepa",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://larevistamusical.blogspot.mx/2010_02_01_archive.html|title=HISTORIAS DE LA REVISTA MUSICAL ESPAÑOLA|website=larevistamusical.blogspot.mx|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> Rosa Valenty, Africa Pratt and the French Marlène Mourreau.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marlenemourreau.com/index.php|title=Official biography of Marlène Mourreau(in French)|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120112202909/http://www.marlenemourreau.com/index.php#|archive-date=2012-01-12|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
In the last years they have emphasized figures like [[La Terremoto de Alcorcón]] and the transsexual actresses ´[[Bibiana Fernandez]], [[La Veneno]] and [[La Prohibida]].
==The Americas==
===Argentina=== [[File:Tita Merello.jpg|thumb|left|150px|[[Tita Merello]]]] [[File:Susana Giménez crop 2014.jpg|thumb|right|[[Susana Giménez]] in 2014]] Revue shows were popularized in [[Buenos Aires]] from the 1920s, mainly in the Teatro Maipo.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1006566-la-catedral-de-la-revista|title=La catedral de la revista|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> [[Tita Merello]] became one of the most famous vedettes of the time.<ref>[http://www.lanacion.com.ar/461482-adios-a-la-inigualable-morocha-argentina Article about Tita Merello in ''La Nación'']</ref>
In the 1950s vedettes of [[Cuba]]n origin appeared, like [[Blanquita Amaro]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tangoreporter.blogspot.com/2009/07/blanquita-amaro-la-bailarina-cubana-que.html|title=TANGO Reporter: Blanquita Amaro, la bailarina cubana que entre rumbas y tangos triunfo en la Argentina|first=Tango|last=Reporter|date=25 July 2009|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> [[Amelia Vargas]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://es.goldenmap.com/Amelita_Vargas|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140818112616/http://es.goldenmap.com/Amelita_Vargas|dead-url=yes|archive-date=18 August 2014|title=Conceptical|date=18 August 2014|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> and [[Rosita Fornés]].<ref>[http://tonypisani1.tripod.com/id1.html Rosita Fornés Official page]</ref> They had all the glitz, grace and glamor that characterized the era, and shared the stage with local stars like [[Nélida Roca]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/163948-nelida-roca-adios-a-un-mito-porteno|title=Nélida Roca: adiós a un mito porteño|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref>
In the 1960s appeared figures like [[Zulma Faiad]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0265311/|title=Zulma Faiad|website=IMDb|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> [[Nélida Lobato]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1128941-nelida-lobato-una-vedette-como-ya-no-hay|title=Nélida Lobato, una vedette como ya no hay|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> [[Susana Brunetti]], [[Norma Pons]], Egle Martín<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pagina12.com.ar/diario/suplementos/las12/13-3979-2008-03-21.html|title=Página/12 :: las12|website=www.pagina12.com.ar|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> and the [[Puerto Rico|Puerto Rican]] [[Iris Chacón]], called the "Vedette of America".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prpop.org/biografias/i_bios/iris_chacon.shtml|title=Iris Chacón|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref>
The 1970s and 1980s gave way to other stars like [[Graciela Alfano]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1295526-graciela-alfano-me-encanta-que-me-crean-mala|title=Graciela Alfano: "Me encanta que me crean mala"|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> and the sisters [[Ethel Rojo|Ethel]] and [[Gogó Rojo]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.clarin.com/espectaculos/television-y-radio/Ethel-gogo-rojo_0_500949937.html|title=Ethel y Gogo Rojo|first=|last=Clarín.com|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> Others who arose at that time and remained in force in the following years were [[Susana Giménez]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.1modelos.com.ar/susana-gimenez.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111103164906/http://www.1modelos.com.ar/susana-gimenez.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=3 November 2011|title=Susana Giménez .|date=3 November 2011|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> [[Moria Casán]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gente.com.ar/nota.php?ID=5974|title=Revista Gente|website=Infobae|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> and Bettina Vardé.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nuestrosactores.com.ar/index.php/component/content/article/19-actrices/895-varde-bettina|title=Vardé, Bettina|first=|last=Mariano|website=www.nuestrosactores.com.ar|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref>
In the 1990s, new vedettes appeared, some of whose fame would spread to the next decade, such as Cris Miró,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://edant.clarin.com/diario/1999/06/02/e-03801d.htm|title=Murió Cris Miró, una figura de la revista|first=|last=Clarín.com|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> María Fernanda Callejón, the [[Puerto Rico|Puerto Rican]] [[Lourdes Chacón]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.primerahora.com/entretenimiento/farandula/nota/lavedettenomueresetransforma-480557/|title=Article in Spanish:The Vedette doesn't die: They transform|last=|first=|date=2011-03-05|work=Primera Hora|access-date=2017-03-25|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://lourdeschacon.wordpress.com/la-vedette-revelacion-del-1981-1982/|title=Article: La Vedette Revelación del 1981-1982|last=|first=|date=2017-02-23|work=Lourdes Chacón|access-date=2017-03-25|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://lourdeschacon.wordpress.com/premio-buho-de-oro/|title=Article: Vedette of the decade: "Golden Owl" Award. (Premio Búho de Oro)|last=|first=|date=2017-02-20|work=Lourdes Chacón|access-date=2017-03-25|language=en-US}}</ref> and [[Monica Ayos]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.clarin.com/espectaculos/television-y-radio/titulo_0_589141115.html|title=Mónica Ayos: "Toda la vida me gustaron los desafíos"|first=|last=Clarín.com|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref>
In the first years of the 21st century there is a return of the revues in the [[Avenida Corrientes]] with figures like [[Florencia de la V]],<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://famosos.ciudad.com.ar/famosos/florencia-de-la-v |title=Article about Florencia de la V |access-date=2017-01-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151025195430/http://famosos.ciudad.com.ar/famosos/florencia-de-la-v |archive-date=2015-10-25 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> [[María Eugenia Ritó]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://maria-eugenia-rito.elarchivon.com/biografia-de-maria-eugenia-rito.php|title=Biography of María Eugenia Ritó|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305194340/http://maria-eugenia-rito.elarchivon.com/biografia-de-maria-eugenia-rito.php|archive-date=5 March 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> [[Adabel Guerrero]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.adabelguerrero.com/|title=HugeDomains.com - AdabelGuerrero.com is for sale (Adabel Guerrero)|website=www.adabelguerrero.com|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> and [[Valeria Archimó]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.primeraplanamundial.com/espectaculos/201002093683/Teatro/valeria-archimo-la-mejor-vedette-de-carlos-paz.html# |title=Article about Valeria Archimó |access-date=2017-01-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160330204156/http://primeraplanamundial.com/espectaculos/201002093683/Teatro/valeria-archimo-la-mejor-vedette-de-carlos-paz.html# |archive-date=2016-03-30 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
===Mexico=== [[File:Lupe Velez - Mexican Spitfire.jpg|thumbnail|right|170px|[[Lupe Vélez]]]] The image of the Vedette in Mexico arises from the beginning of the 20th century with the rise of the called "Carpas" and the [[Revue]]s. Some venues such as Teatro Principal,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://museoebc.org/eventos/historia-del-teatro-principal-en-mexico-1753-1931|title=Historia del Teatro Principal en México 1753-1931 - Museo EBC|website=museoebc.org|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> the Teatro Colón<ref>{{cite web|url=http://edant.clarin.com/diario/2007/08/20/opinion/o-01802.htm|title=El Teatro Colón, en el D.F. de México|last=Clarín.com|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> and the Teatro Arbeu<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ciudadanosenred.com.mx/el-teatro-arbeu/|title=EL TEATRO ARBEU - Ciudadanos en Red|date=2 July 2009|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> were considered as the cathedral of the revues and burlesque in [[Mexico City]]. There arise figures like [[Lupe Vélez]], who, before being consecrated as a star in [[Hollywood]], was considered one of the queens of the frivolous theater.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abcguionistas.com/noticias/guion/11111111111111111111111111111113ek/martin-caballero-presenta-su-biopic-sobre-lupe-velez.html|title=Martín Caballero presenta su 'biopic' sobre Lupe Vélez|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> The maximum figure of the time was [[Maria Conesa]] "The White Kitten", who also had a very long career spanning theater, film and television.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://maria-conesa-tiple.blogspot.com/|title=María Conesa: La artista, la mujer y el mito|first=Roberto|last=Acuña|date=8 August 2011|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> Other outstanding figures of the time were Esperanza Iris,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.biografiasyvidas.com/biografia/i/iris.htm|title=Biografia de Esperanza Iris|website=www.biografiasyvidas.com|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> Celia Montalván,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cinesilentemexicano.wordpress.com/2009/10/14/l/|title=Las tiples y el cine mudo|date=14 October 2009|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> Lupe Rivas Cacho,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://miguelangelmoralex-comicos.blogspot.com/2011/07/lupe-rivas-cacho.html|title=LUPE RIVAS CACHO|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> [[Amparo Arozamena]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/notas/595081.html|title=El Universal - - Perfil: María Amparo Arozamena Sánchez|first=|last=|website=www.eluniversal.com.mx|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> [[Prudencia Grifell]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://revistaactual.com.mx/2011/06/prudencia-griffel-41-aniversario-luctuoso/Article|title=about Prudencia Griffel|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Celia Padilla,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://es.pinterest.com/pin/409264684861728019/|title=TEATRO MEXICANO|website=Pinterest|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> [[Delia Magaña]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.museocjv.com/deliamagana.htm|title=Museo CJV|website=www.museocjv.com|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> Lupe Inclán, Aurora Walker, Amelia Wilhelmy<ref>{{cite web|url=http://reliquiasideologicas.blogspot.com/2010/01/w.html|title=Reliquias Ideológicas: W|date=1 April 2010|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> and [[Mimí Derba]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://revistaactual.com.mx/2011/07/mimi-derba-58-aniversario-luctuoso/|title=Article about Mimí Derba|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131213110942/http://revistaactual.com.mx/2011/07/mimi-derba-58-aniversario-luctuoso/#|archive-date=2013-12-13|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> among others. Conesa, Montalván and Rivas Cacho, were even immortalized in a famous [[foxtrot]] called ''Mi querido capitán (My dear captain)''.
In the 1950s<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.20minutos.es/noticia/1090805/0/eujenia-arenas/cabarets/mexico/|title=Los últimos cabarets mexicanos|last=20Minutos|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018|date=2011-06-24}}</ref> saw a resurgence of nightlife in Mexico City. Venues like the Tivoli, the Waikikí, the Margo (after the Teatro Blanquita), the Follies Bergere and the Teatro Lírico,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.urban360.com.mx/239792/por-las-calles-de-la-ciudad-teatro-lirico/|title=''Article about the Teatro Lírico''|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171003224958/http://news.urban360.com.mx/239792/por-las-calles-de-la-ciudad-teatro-lirico/#|archive-date=2017-10-03|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> among others, became the main forums for the blossoming of the vedettes. Special mention should be made of the ''Exoticas'', a group of vedettes that caused fury in Mexico's nightlife in the late 1940s and early 1950s. These "Exoticas" were characterized by using extravagant names, and their shows included African, Tahitian or Oriental dances.<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://www.revistas.inah.gob.mx/index.php/diariodecampo/article/view/859|title=Tongolele y las "exóticas" en Magazine de Policía y VEA|first=Gabriela Pulido|last=Llano|date=1 October 2013|journal=Diario de Campo|issue=13|pages=32–36|accessdate=2 July 2018|via=www.revistas.inah.gob.mx|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180702093257/https://www.revistas.inah.gob.mx/index.php/diariodecampo/article/view/859#|archive-date=2018-07-02|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> The most famous of the "Exoticas" was [[Tongolele|Yolanda Montes "Tongolele"]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vivelohoy.com/entretenimiento/8041423/perfume-de-gardenia-arranca-gira-en-la|title=Perfume de Gardenia arranca gira en LA|first=Tommy|last=Calle|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> one of the most important dancers of Latin America, and has been in force for more than sixty years. Together with ''Tongolele'', the most famous were [[Su Muy Key]] ''The Chinese Doll'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://miguelangelmoralex-bitacora.blogspot.com/2010/05/su-muy-key.html|title=Bitácora: SU-MUY-KEY|first=Miguel Angel|last=Morales|date=1 May 2010|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> and [[Mary Ellen Bromfield|Kalantan]]. Another famous "Exóticas" were Trudi Bora, Turanda, Joyce Cameron, Tanabonga, Tundra, Gemma, Eda Lorna, Kurumba, Bongala, Tula Montenegro, Brenda Conde, Josefina del Mar and Naná.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.poresto.net/ver_nota.php?zona=yucatan&idSeccion=33&idTitulo=94881|title=''Por esto Yucatán: The Amazing World of the Exoticas''|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> Parallel to the success of the Exoticas, they appear in Mexico the famous "Rumberas", dancers of Afro-American rhythms. The Rumberas managed to create their own cinematographic genre: The [[Rumberas film]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cinemexicano.mty.itesm.mx/rumbarr.html|title=1946-1950: Rumberas y Arrabal|website=cinemexicano.mty.itesm.mx|accessdate=2 July 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120222034740/http://cinemexicano.mty.itesm.mx/rumbarr.html#|archive-date=2012-02-22|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> In the called [[Golden Age of Mexican cinema]]. The Rumberas films reflected in many of its arguments the life of the women in the night centers and cabarets. The main exponents of the genre were the Cubans [[María Antonieta Pons]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0690512/bio|title=María Antonieta Pons|website=IMDb|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> [[Amalia Aguilar]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.amaliaaguilar.com/history_1.html|title=Amalia Aguilar - Beginnings|website=www.amaliaaguilar.com|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> [[Ninón Sevilla]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www2.esmas.com/entretenimiento/biografias/022450/ninon-sevilla|title=Ninón Sevilla|last=Espectáculos|date=2 January 2015|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> and [[Rosa Carmina]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rincondelaanoranza.blogspot.com/search?q=rosa+carmina|title=El Rincón de la Añoranza|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> as well the Mexican [[Meche Barba]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rincondelaanoranza.blogspot.com/2008/09/las-rumberas-parte-4-la-rumbera.html|title=El Rincón de la Añoranza: LAS RUMBERAS parte 4: LA RUMBERA MEXICANA... MECHE BARBA|first=René Muñoz|last=López|date=1 September 2008|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> These women were complete vedettes who never needed to explicitly teach their bodies, captivating audiences only with their dances and other stage talents. The Rumberas also performed shows and live performances in important venues. With the decline of the Rumberas film in the mid-fifties, some rumberas broadened their horizons and ventured into vedette shows. Particularly remembered are the live shows of Amalia Aguilar and Rosa Carmina, who even filled stadiums in various countries in Central and South America. The Cuban [[Rosita Fornés]] deserves special mention. She reaches the final consecration in Mexico before conquering the rest of the continent.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cinemexicano.mty.itesm.mx/estrellas/rosita_fornes.html|title=Rosita Fornés|website=cinemexicano.mty.itesm.mx|accessdate=2 July 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130704020007/http://cinemexicano.mty.itesm.mx/estrellas/rosita_fornes.html#|archive-date=2013-07-04|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
In the 1960s the splendor of the vedettes in Mexico lost force. Even so, worthy of mention are the shows offered in venues such as the Blanquita Theater or "El Patio" by the stars such as [[Sonia Furió]], [[Ana Luisa Peluffo]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.poresto.net/ver_nota.php?zona=yucatan&idSeccion=33&idTitulo=97347|title=''Por esto Yucatán: Ana Luisa Peluffo|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> and [[Ana Bertha Lepe]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elanecdotario.com/2006/ago06/7/ago7a.htm|title=''Article about Ana Bertha Lepe''|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> In the midst of the fury of the [[Rock and Roll]] era, were famous figures like Malú Reyes<ref>{{cite web|url=http://estroncio90.typepad.com/blog/2011/12/malu-reyes.html|title=Malu Reyes - Vuelve Primavera: El rock de los 60 en México|website=estroncio90.typepad.com|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> and Emily Cranz.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.venamimundo.com/Videos/EmilyCranz.html|title=Emily Cranz|website=www.venamimundo.com|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> Actresses such as [[Jacqueline Voltaire]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.articulosiete.com/content/qu%C3%A9-se-fi%C3%A7ieron-las-chicas-go-go|title=''ArtículoSiete.com: The A Go go Girls''|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170305041541/http://www.articulosiete.com//content/qu%C3%A9-se-fi%C3%A7ieron-las-chicas-go-go|archive-date=5 March 2017|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and [[Irán Eory]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://diariojudio.com/comunidad-judia-mexico/iran-eory-zl-leyenda-del-cine-y-la-television-mexicana/7463/#|title=Iran Eory Z'L, Leyenda del Cine y la Televisión Mexicana - Diario Judío: Diario de la Vida Judía en México y el Mundo|website=diariojudio.com|accessdate=2 July 2018|date=2015-02-10}}</ref> also performed shows as vedettes.
The 1970s and 1980s are considered the golden era of the vedettes in Mexico, thanks to a massive revival of nightlife in the country's capital. Mexico City was flooded with nightclubs, cabarets of all levels and burlesque theaters where the vedettes began to bloom. Among the most important nightclubs that illuminated the capital of the country are the Terazza Casino, the Capri (from the Hotel Regis), the Imperial, the Minuet, the Rio Rosa, La Fuente, El Conjunto Marrakech, La Copa de Champagne, El Cordiale, El Rondinella, El Clóset, El Quid, El 77, the Impala Bar and the Belvedere of the Hilton Continental Hotel. Some cabarets such as La Burbuja, Montparnasse, Las Fabulosas, El Can-Can, Los Globos, King Kong and Savoy also reached a great boom, while theaters like El Iris, El Blanquita and the [[Teatro Fru Fru]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.revistacinefagia.com/2004/07/tivoli/|title=Tívoli - revistacinefagia.com|first=Revista|last=Cinefagia|website=www.revistacinefagia.com|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> presented burlesque shows, where the shows were more audacious and explicit. In addition, thanks to television, movies and magazines, the vedettes in Mexico reached their highest point of popularity. Many of them also ventured into the cinema, within the so-called [[Mexican sex comedy]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cinemexicano.mty.itesm.mx/ficheras.html|title=1976-1982: Los años de las "Ficheras"|website=cinemexicano.mty.itesm.mx|accessdate=2 July 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130801011320/http://cinemexicano.mty.itesm.mx/ficheras.html#|archive-date=2013-08-01|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> On the other hand, the popular television program ''Variedades de medianoche (Varieties of the Midnight)'' contributed to the boom of these women and launched to the fame to dozens of them.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cinematerapia.blogspot.mx/2011/12/variedades-de-medianoche-1977.html|title=''Cinematerapia: Variedades de Medianoche''|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171106190012/http://cinematerapia.blogspot.mx/2011/12/variedades-de-medianoche-1977.html#|archive-date=2017-11-06|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
[[File:rossymendoza.jpg|thumb|right|170px|[[Rossy Mendoza]]]]
Among the legendary vedettes that illuminated the nightlife of Mexico City are [[Olga Breeskin]] also known as "Super Olga" who achieved great fame for her spectacular performances where she danced surrounded by dancers and exotic animals while playing the violin;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.durangomas.mx/2013/10/olga-breeskin/|title=Olga Breeskin - DurangoMas|date=23 October 2013|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> Angélica Chaín,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sarpanet.info/angelica_chain/|title=Angelica Chain - Biografía, fotos, palmarés, vídeos -|first=© Sarpanet, Diseño|last=Web|website=www.sarpanet.info|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> who achieved fame first in magazines, then start a career as a vedette and finally consecrate herself in the cinema; Amira Cruzat, famous for her show known as ''The Dressing Room of Amira Cruzat'';<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archivo.eluniversal.com.mx/espectaculos/24254.html|title=¿Qué hacen hoy las vedettes de los años 70?|first=El Universal, Compañia Periodística Nacional.|last=México|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> [[Lila Deneken]] "The Number One", important singer and the first Latin American star to present a show at the [[Monte-Carlo Sporting]] Club;<ref>{{cite web|url=https://nardaaraceli.wordpress.com/2011/02/20/recordando-a-lila-deneken/|title=Recordando a Lila Deneken.|date=20 February 2011|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> the Argentine [[Zulma Faiad]] who settled in Mexico much of the decade of the 1970s and reached a great fame in cinema and night centers;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sarpanet.info/zulma_faiad/index.php|title=Zulma Faiad - Biografía, fotos, palmarés, vídeos -|first=© Sarpanet, Diseño|last=Web|website=www.sarpanet.info|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> Gloriella, popular star of the burlesque and numerous movies;<ref>[http://www.revistacinefagia.com/2005/12/se-llamaba-gloriella/ Cinefagia.com: Article about Gloriella'']</ref> [[Princesa Lea]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://laprincesalea.blogspot.com/|title=LA PRINCESA LEA|first=Los Jinetes De|last=Acero|date=13 July 2007|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> very popular for presenting a show in which she bathed in a glass of champagne; [[Lyn May]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://aztecanoreste.mx/videos/detalle/8200?seccion_id=Entretenimiento|title=''Azteca Noreste: Lyn May''|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220140105/http://aztecanoreste.mx/videos/detalle/8200?seccion_id=Entretenimiento|archive-date=20 December 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> of Chinese ancestry, pioneer of the nudes and one of the principal stars of the burlesque; [[Rossy Mendoza]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cinepapaya.com/mx/biografia/rossy-mendoza-18822|title=Rossy Mendoza - Fandango México|website=www.cinepapaya.com|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> known popularly as "The Body" or "The Shorter Waist", thanks to her impressive anatomy; [[Sasha Montenegro]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sdpnoticias.com/sdp/contenido/2009/01/19/312258|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131215195101/http://www.sdpnoticias.com/sdp/contenido/2009/01/19/312258|dead-url=yes|archive-date=15 December 2013|title=SDPnoticias.com|date=15 December 2013|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> who on par of her film career performed live shows that attracted the public because of her popularity; The Brazilian Gina Montes, famous by her appearance in a popular TV Show;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.debate.com.mx/show/Gina-de-simbolo-sexual-a-cocinera-y-chofer--20160104-0174.html|title=Gina, de símbolo sexual a cocinera y chofer|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> [[Grace Renat]], ''The Goddess of the Night'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archivo.eluniversal.com.mx/espectaculos/24254.html|title=¿Qué hacen hoy las vedettes de los años 70?|first=El Universal, Compañia Periodística Nacional.|last=México|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> [[Irma Serrano]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://famosasmexicanas.com/fotos/irma-serrano/irma-serrano.htm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160308155518/http://famosasmexicanas.com/fotos/irma-serrano/irma-serrano.htm|dead-url=yes|archive-date=8 March 2016|title=famosasmexicanas.com at Directnic|date=8 March 2016|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> who scandalized at the time with her controversial theatrical spectacles in the enclosure of her property, the Theater Fru-Frú; [[Wanda Seux]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.informador.com.mx/entretenimiento/2009/150583/6/naci-vedette-y-morire-vedette-wanda-seux.htm|title=Nací vedette y moriré vedette: Wanda Seux|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> called "The Golden Bomb" and considered the "Barbie" of the vedettes for her thin figure and blonde hair; [[Thelma Tixou]] "The Girl of the Golden Body",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://silacasadelosperezgarcia.blogspot.com/2009/06/thelma-tixouuna-vedette-de-los-80.html|title=sílacasadelospérezgarcía: THELMA TIXOU,UNA VEDETTE DE LOS 80|last=Gallega|date=24 January 2010|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> native of Argentina, famous for her stature and imposing physique, and star for several years of the famous cabaret El Capri, [[Isela Vega]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mx.globedia.com/vedette-mexicana-nunca-objeto-sexual-deseo-entrevista-isela-vega|title=Vedette Mexicana: "Nunca objeto sexual, pero sí del deseo" Entrevista a ...|website=mx.globedia.com|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> popular Mexican film actress, who scandalized audiences with her provocative shows in the stage, and [[Princesa Yamal]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://acatani.blogspot.com/2011/05/princesa-yamalestrella-de-los-80.html|title=PRINCESA YAMAL...ESTRELLA DE LOS 80|first=Alberto|last=Catani|date=11 May 2011|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> famous by her Arabian exotic dances.
Other outstanding figures were Brigitte Aubé, Cleopatra,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://miguelangelmoralex-bitacora.blogspot.com/2015/01/mis-amigas-las-vedettes.html|title=Bitácora: MIS AMIGAS LAS VEDETTES|first=Miguel Angel|last=Morales|date=22 January 2015|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> Alejandra del Moral,<ref>{{cite In the year 2016, the filmmaker María José Cuevas made the documentary ''[[Beauties of the Night (documentary)|Beauties of the Night]]'', which portrays the life of five of these great vedettes.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://arca.tv/bellas-noche-documental-las-vedettes-mexicanas/ |title=Arca.tv: Beauties of the Night, documentary about the Mexican vedettes'' |access-date=2016-12-06 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161129144336/http://arca.tv/bellas-noche-documental-las-vedettes-mexicanas/ |archive-date=2016-11-29 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
One of the last great vedettes in Mexico was [[Francis García]], a transvestite artist who was the main star of the Teatro Blanquita for more than a decade.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cronica.com.mx/notas/2007/327337.html|title=Muere Francis a causa de una trombosis|website=www.cronica.com.mx|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> In recent years, large night centers have virtually disappeared from Mexico. Some actresses and singers perform shows of vedettes in other venues, such as the ''Palenques''. Among them are figures such as [[Costa Rica]]n [[Maribel Guardia]],<ref>[http://www2.esmas.com/entretenimiento/farandula/fotos/antes-y-despues-de-la-ardiente-maribel-guardia-/68832/ Esmas.com: Article about Maribel Guardia'']</ref> Mexicans [[Lorena Herrera]], [[Mariana Seoane]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.info7.mx/seccion/mariana-seoane-la-nueva-gardenia/692156y|title=''Article about Mariana Seoane''|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> the transgender [[Alejandra Bogue]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://infouam.blogspot.com/2006/03/alejandra-bogue-de-tiempo-completo.html|title=infouam: Alejandra Bogue, de tiempo completo©|first=Israel|last=Pintor|date=24 March 2006|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> and [[Ninel Conde]] and the Cubans [[Niurka Marcos]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.terra.com/entretenimiento/noticias/niurka_marcos_toda_una_vedette/oci447490|title=Terra - Notícias, esportes, coberturas ao vivo, diversão e estilo de vida|website=Terra|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> and Lis Vega.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.multimedios.com/programas/vivalavi/lis-vega-gran-vedette-1.html|title=¡Lis Vega sí es una gran vedette!|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref>
===United States===
[[Image:Gypsy Rose Lee NYWTS 1.jpg|thumb|right|[[Gypsy Rose Lee]]]] The term "vedette" is not commonly used in the United States or other Anglo-Saxon countries, (here called "[[showgirl]]s"). [[Las Vegas]] is considered, after Paris, as the main venue for revue shows and musicals worldwide.
The British [[Lydia Thompson]] became a leading dancer and actress in burlesques on the London stage. She introduced Victorian burlesque to America with her troupe the "British Blondes", in 1868, to great acclaim and notoriety.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.streetswing.com/histmai2/d2lydtm1.htm|title=Streetswing's Burlesque History Archives: Lydia Thompson|first=Sonny|last=Watson|website=www.streetswing.com|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref>
Of the most famous American vedettes, stand out [[May Yohé]], one of the most valued figures of the vaudeville at the beginning of the century;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.edwardianpromenade.com/scandal/fascinating-women-may-yohe/|title=Fascinating Women: May Yohé|date=18 January 2010|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> The aforementioned [[Josephine Baker]], who ended up consecrating herself in France, where she was more popular than in her own country; [[Fanny Brice]], star of the famous [[Ziegfeld Follies]], queen of the theater, revues and later also star of cinema and the radio;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.biography.com/people/fanny-brice-9225840|title=Fanny Brice|website=Biography|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> [[Sally Rand]], actress and dancer, specializing in fan dancing, which she popularized at the Paramount Club, and who because of the postures considered indecent she adopted with the dance was sometimes arrested. Also conceived the famous dance of the bubble;<ref>{{cite web|url=https://global.britannica.com/biography/Sally-Rand|title=Sally Rand - American actress and dancer|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> [[Zorita (entertainer)|Zorita]], famous for her shows where she played double roles and for her dances where she used boas and other exotic animals;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://scalar.usc.edu/works/spectacles-of-agency-and-desire/exotic-dancers-and-their-exotic-pets-1|title=Spectacles of Agency and Desire: Exotic Dancers and Celebrities with their Exotic Pets|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> [[Evelyn West]], also known as "The Hubba Hubba Girl", a burlesque legend of the forties, fifties and sixties;<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0922067/|title=Evelyn West|website=IMDb|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> [[Ann Corio]], who also works in several Hollywood films;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.burlesquehall.com/ann-corio/|title=Ann Corio|website=www.burlesquehall.com|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> [[Mae West]], who achieved tremendous fame, first in theater and then in [[Hollywood]], where she scandalized censorship for her provocative behavior and spicy phrases. In the 1950s and 1960s, she achieved fame in her shows, which included groups of dancers and bodybuilders;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.biografiasyvidas.com/biografia/w/west.htm|title=Biografia de Mae West|website=www.biografiasyvidas.com|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> [[Gypsy Rose Lee]], immortalized in the famous autobiographical musical ''[[Gypsy (musical)|Gypsy]]''. Her innovations consisted of a casual style, against the spasmodic movements of other strippers (she emphasized the joke during the striptease) and brought a keen sense of humor to her performances. She was one of the main stars of the [[Minsky's Burlesque]], with whom she worked four years. Working with the Minsky brothers was arrested several times.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lifetimetv.co.uk/biography/biography-gypsy-rose-lee|title=''Biography of Gypsy Rose Lee''|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160127094133/http://www.lifetimetv.co.uk/biography/biography-gypsy-rose-lee|archive-date=27 January 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Another important figure of this time was Novita "The Pixie of Burlesque", one of the founders of the Exotic Dancers League (EDL).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.burlesquehall.com/rip-novita-the-pixie-of-burlesque-1932-2015/|title=RIP Novita, The Pixie of Burlesque (1932-2015)|website=www.burlesquehall.com|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> [[File:SDG Von Teese 2.jpg|thumb|right|[[Dita Von Teese]]]]
In the 1960s and 1970s some burlesque figures peaked in the United States, particularly at the shows offered in Las Vegas. Of these are highlighted [[Tempest Storm]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.burlesquehall.com/tempest-storm/|title=Tempest Storm|website=www.burlesquehall.com|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> [[Lili St. Cyr]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0820506/bio|title=Lili St. Cyr|website=IMDb|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> [[Blaze Starr]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/ca41bb5f0255496f8c811f39b99a7a87/blaze-starr-burlesque-star-linked-governor-dead-83|title=Blaze Starr, burlesque dancer linked to governor, dead at 83|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> [[Tura Satana]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://elpais.com/diario/2011/02/11/necrologicas/1297378802_850215.html|title=Tura Satana, la actriz que inspiró a Tarantino|first=Ediciones El|last=País|date=11 February 2011|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018|via=elpais.com}}</ref> [[Bambi Jones]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.burlesquehall.com/whos-who-in-burlyq-bambi-jones/|title=Bambi Jones|website=www.burlesquehall.com|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> and [[Satan's Angel]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.satansangel.com/|title=Satan's Angel in her official website|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref>
The most important in recent years has been [[Liza Minnelli]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.biografiasyvidas.com/biografia/m/minnelli_liza.htm|title=Biografia de Liza Minnelli|website=www.biografiasyvidas.com|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref>
Today, among the most famous vedettes in the United States are [[Dita Von Teese]], who was the star of Crazy Horse,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elmundo.es/elmundo/2009/02/05/gentes/1233834913.html|title=Dita Von Teese: 'Carla Bruni puede hacer un gran striptease' - Gentes - elmundo.es|first=Unidad Editorial Internet,|last=S.L.|website=www.elmundo.es|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> [[Julie Atlas Muz]],<ref>[http://gothamist.com/2004/06/16/julie_atlas_muz_burlesque_starmermaid.php ''Gothamist.com: Article about Julie Atlas Muz''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091010205528/http://gothamist.com/2004/06/16/julie_atlas_muz_burlesque_starmermaid.php |date=2009-10-10 }}</ref> [[Michelle L'amour]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://michellelamour.com/|title=The Most Naked Woman|website=The Most Naked Woman|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> [[Catherine D'lish]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/05/16/nyregion/long-island-journal-boys-of-every-age-rekindle-old-fantasies.html?_r=0|title=LONG ISLAND JOURNAL; Boys of Every Age Rekindle Old Fantasies|first=Marcelle S.|last=Fischler|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> [[Dirty Martini (burlesque)|Miss Dirty Martini]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.revelinnewyork.com/takeaways/miss-dirty-martini|title=Miss Dirty Martini - Burlesque - Revel in New York created by Scott Newman & Marc Santo|website=www.revelinnewyork.com|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> the British [[Immodesty Blaze]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.ie/entertainment/music/blaize-lands-film-and-record-deal-26583402.html|title=Blaize lands film and record deal - Independent.ie|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> [[Angie Pontani]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://chicago.metromix.com/events/photo/angie-pontani-and-the/618381/content|title=''ChicagoMetromix.com: Angie Pontani''|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> ,[[Jo Weldon]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://coilhouse.net/2010/01/jo-boobs-teaches-the-va-va-voom/|title=Coilhouse » Blog Archive » Jo Boobs Teaches the Va-Va Voom!|website=coilhouse.net|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> and the [[Singapore]]an [[Sukki Singapora]], the first international burlesque artist in Singapore. Singapora became the first burlesque artist in the world to be invited to tea at [[Buckingham Palace]] as a recognition of her contribution to the arts as an Asian model.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timeout.com/singapore/theatre/interview-sukki-singapora|title=Interview: Sukki Singapora|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref>
===Other=== Other prominent vedettes who have appeared in the world are the [[Puerto Rico|Puerto Rican]] [[Iris Chacón]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prpop.org/biografias/i_bios/iris_chacon.shtml|title=Iris Chacón|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> the [[Brazil]]ian [[Luz del Fuego]],<ref>[http://www.e-biografias.net/biografias/luz_del_fuego.php Biografía de Luz del Fuego] (en portugués)</ref> the [[Cuba]]ns [[Chelo Alonso]] and [[Rita Montaner]],<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20120911041300/http://www.dmsgbc.sld.cu/gbcoa/rita.htm Article about Rita Montaner]</ref> the [[Peru]]vian Amparo Brambilla<ref>{{cite web|url=http://s1.accesoperu.com/wp6/wp6.php?p=10506|title= Article about Amparo Branbilla|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> and the [[Venezuela]]n [[Diosa Canales]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.canalesdiosa.com/|title=Diosa Canales in her Official Website|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref>
==Fiction==
===Film=== * Lola-Lola in the film ''[[The Blue Angel]]'' (1930) * Gypsy Rose Lee in the film ''[[Gypsy (1962 film)|Gypsy]]'' (1962) * [[Sally Bowles]] in several works, notably the musical ''[[Cabaret (musical)|Cabaret]]'' (1966) * [[Miss Piggy]] in ''[[The Muppet Show]]'' (1976) * [[Jessica Rabbit]] in the film ''[[Who Framed Roger Rabbit]]'' (1988) * Satine in the film ''[[Moulin Rouge!]]'' (2001) * Roxie Hart in the film ''[[Chicago (2002 film)|Chicago]]'' (2002)
==See also== * [[Burlesque]] * [[Cabaret]] * [[Nightclub act]] * [[Revue]] * [[Showgirl]] * [[Striptease]]
